comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Interestingly, mirrors don't flip things horizontally; They flip them front to back. That's why turning the mirror around doesn't make it flip things vertically instead.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: That's Albert Quay station on the south side of the River Lee in Cork, terminus of the Cork Bandon and South Coast Railway lines, which served Bandon, Bantry, Baltimore etc...Photo is taken sometime after the West Cork lines closed in 1961, as evident by the dereliction. View is from the now demolished Hibernian Road bridge, looking north towards the terminus. The yard remained in use for freight traffic until 1976. Here's an identical view before it was closed altogether!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/flyingsnail] Excellent as always! Thank you.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/flyingsnail] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Agh. A Cork one. About Albert Quay. And I bloody missed it :) Nothing to add to Flying Snail's excellent notes and tags. Other than to offer a link to some further photos of the site/station - including a shot of the bridge from which the photo above was taken.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] Richard Bulter's site of the CBSCR is an excellent one, covering the whole route photographically. Just a final mention from me, cine footage of Albert Quay and the intricate city railway before its demise. Some of the buildings are recognisable from the photo.

comment.author: 55955471@N06
comment._content: I would like to know when that metal bridge from which the photo was taken was demolished. The suspension bridge there now was put up in the 1980s or so. Also, interesting to see how the train shed had been boarded up and the tracks leading to it taken up by 1967 - the train was intact well beyond Ballinhassig as late as 1965. As you can see here the track to the left was not touched - this went across the city to Glanmire Road. The colour photo above is a service en route to that station. This was done away with, as Flying Snail above comments, in 1976. In 1965, some of the old name signs for stations west of Cork were discarded on the platforms near the train shed. The Bandon ones were caught on a film-reel: beneathesummergrowth.files.wordpress.com/2012/12/bandon-n... These would have some value today if someone had the foresight to save them!

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/flyingsnail] Thanks a lot for sharing! Never saw that video before. It's great. Will repost to the related photo.
